channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Restoration Puzzle
item.description: In the Yungang Grottoes of China, Zhang Juncai is battling to restore ancient Buddhist artifacts broken by vandals and ravaged by pollution.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH KESSEL

item.title: India Ink: Congress’s Rank and File Lament Demise of Party Once Beloved
item.description: Theories abound for the Indian National Congress’s reversal of fortunes, but workers gathered at the party headquarters during the vote count said the culture of the leadership had changed.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Chief of Syria’s Air Defense Dies in Battle Near Capital
item.description: The impact of the death of Lt. Gen. Hussein Ayoub Ishaq was unclear, an expert said, because successors usually await and rebel forces have no aircraft.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Catastrophic Floods Hit Balkans, Raising Fears for Land Mines and Power Plants
item.description: Torrential rains have fed flooding that has killed dozens in Serbia and Bosnia, with officials saying the region has not seen damage on the same scale since in the 1992-95 civil war.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: South Korea to Disband Coast Guard, Leader Vows
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea vowed on Monday to disband her country’s Coast Guard because of its failures in a ferry disaster.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Listening Post: As U.S. Looks to Nuclear Deal, Book Faults Handling of Iranian Defector
item.description: A new book asserts that an Iranian intelligence officer who is living in the United States under C.I.A. protection oversaw the bombing of the American Embassy in 1983.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: The American Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, after an April 1983 attack, said to be overseen by an Iranian intelligence officer.

item.title: Afghan Lovers’ Plight Shaking Up the Lives of Those Left in Their Wake
item.description: However matters eventually turn out for the Afghan Romeo and Juliet who eloped into hiding, a happily-ever-after ending is eluding many of those whose lives crossed theirs.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali. A happily-ever-after ending is eluding many of those whose lives crossed theirs in Afghanistan.

item.title: Ex-General Claims Responsibility for Libyan Parliament Attack
item.description: Militia members using antiaircraft weapons, rocket-propelled grenades and light arms engaged Sunday in some of the heaviest clashes in months in Tripoli.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Masinloc Journal: A Leviathan Turns Philippine Fishermen Into Desperate Darters
item.description: In a dispute over Scarborough Shoal, Chinese patrols have been chasing away Filipinos whose hometown, Masinloc, depends on fish from the reef.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Workers at N.Y.U.’s Abu Dhabi Site Faced Harsh Conditions
item.description: Many migrant workers who helped in the building of New York University’s new campus live in a grim environment despite a statement of labor values issued by the university to improve their treatment.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ARIEL KAMINER and SEAN O’DRISCOLL
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrant workers, in their tiny apartment in Abu Dhabi, earn as little as $272 a month while building a campus for New York University.

item.title: Turkey Arrests Several Executives Over Mining Disaster
item.description: The initial report about the possible causes of the accident compiled by investigators said that the fire in the mine was not caused by a transformer explosion as originally suggested but by smoldering coal that ignited.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: At Least 32 Children Die in Fire on Crowded Bus in Colombia
item.description: An overcrowded bus carrying young people home from a church service caught fire on Sunday in the northern city of Fundación, and at least 32 children were killed, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Front-Runner in Ukraine Election May Be Shifting Putin’s Stance
item.description: With Ukraine still roiled by separatist violence in the east, the growing air of inevitability around Petro Poroshenko, a confection magnate, has redrawn the Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Petro Poroshenko, a pro-Western billionaire known as a pragmatist, has business interests in Russia.

item.title: A Jihadist’s Face Taunts Nigeria From the Shadows
item.description: Nigerian officials had claimed to have killed Abubakar Shekau, a Boko Haram leader, but his apparent emergence in a video of kidnapped girls has brought attention to his long record of harsh rhetoric and ferocious violence.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Benedicte Kurzen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nigerian children studying the Quran in the area where Abubakar Shekau, the Boko Haram leader, was once educated.

item.title: Mali Rebels Attack and Seize Hostages
item.description: Eight soldiers were killed and 30 hostages taken in an attack apparently prompted by a visit to a northern city by the newly appointed prime minister.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ex-Trader’s Pilgrimage Culminates in Jail Cell
item.description: Jérôme Kerviel resumed his pilgrimage from Rome late Sunday, ahead of a midnight deadline for him to turn himself in to the French authorities.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Jérôme Kerviel, center, heading toward the French border.

item.title: BlackBerry’s Partnership With Foxconn Signals Shifting Priorities
item.description: The company’s deal in Indonesia with the parts manufacturer could aid its plan to focus on services and software rather than phones, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE and IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: John S. Chen, BlackBerry’s chief executive, with the company’s Z3 smartphone, designed and distributed by Foxconn.

item.title: On Anniversary, a Victory Parade and a Crackdown in Sri Lanka
item.description: The security measures, in Tamil-dominated areas, were apparently intended to prevent demonstrations by relatives of those killed in the civil war.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Note to Olympic Sailors: Don’t Fall in Rio’s Water
item.description: Guanabara Bay, the venue for the 2016 events, is so foul that a biologist called it “a latrine” and a Brazilian sailor said he has encountered bodies.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:credit: Ana Carolina Fernandes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vast amounts of raw sewage leak into the waters of Rio's Guanabara Bay, where the sailing and windsurfing events will take place during the 2016 Summer Olympics.

item.title: Swiss Voters Defeat $24.65 Minimum Wage by a Wide Margin
item.description: Swiss voters on Sunday resoundingly rejected a proposed minimum wage that would have been the world’s highest.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Sorcery at War
item.description: Belief in witchcraft is fueling the fearsome violence in C.A.R.
item.dc:creator: By GRAEME WOOD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Belgians Agree to Differ
item.description: The nation persists because Flemings and Walloons can't decide on a better idea.
item.dc:creator: By KHALED DIAB

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Vote for Ukrainian Freedom
item.description: If we are to foil Putin's plan to subjugate our country, the success of this election is vital.
item.dc:creator: By YULIA V. TYMOSHENKO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Stop Italy’s Soccer Hooligans
item.description: Zero tolerance ended the mayhem in Britain; it can work in Italy, too.
item.dc:creator: By BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Vietnamese Police Block Anti-Chinese Demonstrators After Violence Over Oil Rig
item.description: Police guards around Chinese buildings in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City effectively ended a week of protests over a Chinese oil rig in disputed waters.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers told people to leave outside the Chinese Embassy in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Sunday.
